exception.name: ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow
exception.description: This exception is thrown if the signature counter reaches its logical maximum value. The signature counter is a monotonically increasing value that provides audit trail integrity and replay attack protection for transactions. The counter has a maximum value (e.g., 2^64-1 for a 64-bit counter) and cannot be incremented further once this maximum is reached. ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow indicates that the signature counter has reached its logical limit and cannot accept new transactions. This is an extremely rare condition that typically requires device replacement or counter reset procedures. Common causes include: device has processed an extraordinarily large number of transactions over its lifetime, counter implementation limits reached, or counter not properly designed for system lifetime.

javadoc.summary: This class defines the exception ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow that is thrown if the signature counter reaches its logical maximum.
javadoc.description: This exception is thrown when the signature counter reaches its logical maximum value and cannot be incremented further. The signature counter is a critical component that maintains a monotonically increasing counter for transaction signatures, providing audit trail integrity and replay attack protection. The counter has a defined maximum value (implementation-dependent, e.g., 2^64-1 for a 64-bit counter). ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow indicates that the counter has reached this logical limit. This is an extremely rare condition in practice because the maximum is typically very large. Common causes include: device has processed an extraordinarily large number of transactions (billions or trillions), counter design does not match system transaction volume, or counter has been in production for an exceptionally long time with high transaction load. ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow is a Critical severity exception because it permanently prevents transaction processing. The counter cannot wrap around to zero (which would compromise audit trail integrity). The device is effectively unusable and requires replacement or counter reset procedures.

specification.section: 3.3.2 Transaction Operations and 3.3.3 Logging Operations - Signature Counter Management
specification.requirement: The Secure Element maintains a signature counter that is incremented for each transaction, providing audit trail integrity and replay attack protection. The signature counter is monotonically increasing and has a defined maximum value (implementation-dependent). When the signature counter reaches its logical maximum value, the device cannot increment it further and SHALL raise ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow on any operation requiring counter increment (startTransaction, updateTransaction, finishTransaction, configureLogging). The device must not accept new transactions when counter is at maximum, as wrapping to zero would compromise audit trail integrity. This is an extremely rare condition expected to occur only after processing an extraordinarily large number of transactions over many years.
specification.applicability: Transaction operations requiring signature counter increment: startTransaction, updateTransaction, finishTransaction, configureLogging
specification.reference: Transaction Operations (3.3.2), Logging Operations (3.3.3), Signature Counter Management

condition.scenario: Signature counter reaches logical maximum value
condition.description: The signature counter has been incremented to its maximum possible value
condition.trigger: A startTransaction call is made but the device detects the signature counter is already at maximum value (e.g., 2^64-1). ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow is raised because the counter cannot be incremented further.

condition.scenario: Extremely high transaction volume over device lifetime
condition.description: The device has processed an extraordinarily large number of transactions
condition.trigger: After many years of production operation with very high transaction load, a finishTransaction call detects the signature counter has reached maximum. ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow is raised.

condition.scenario: Counter size insufficient for system requirements
condition.description: The counter implementation uses insufficient bit width for the system's transaction volume
condition.trigger: An updateTransaction call is made but counter reaches maximum because the counter size is too small for the system's transaction rate. ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow is raised.

condition.scenario: Signature counter increment operation would overflow
condition.description: The next increment operation would cause the counter to exceed its maximum value
condition.trigger: A configureLogging call attempts to enable more transactions but the counter cannot be incremented further. ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow is raised to prevent overflow.

condition.scenario: Device approaching or at theoretical maximum transaction limit
condition.description: The device is at or approaching the theoretical maximum transactions it can support
condition.trigger: Any transaction operation detects the counter is at maximum. The device has reached its absolute transaction processing limit.

executionSequence.step: User/application calls transaction operation that requires signature counter increment (e.g., startTransaction)
Function initiates communication with Secure Element
Secure Element checks current signature counter value
If counter is at maximum → ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow raised, operation aborted
If counter is below maximum → proceed to step 6
Secure Element calculates new counter value = current counter + 1
Secure Element verifies new counter does not exceed maximum
If new counter would exceed maximum → ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow raised, operation aborted
If new counter is valid → proceed to step 9
Secure Element writes updated counter value to storage
Secure Element returns result to function

recovery.step: Stop accepting new transactions immediately - counter is at maximum and cannot increment
Review error message - understand the signature counter overflow status
Query device state - determine current signature counter value and maximum
Export all transaction logs - export complete transaction history while device is operational
Archive transaction history - backup all records for compliance and audit purposes
Calculate device lifetime - determine how long device has been in operation and transaction volume
Notify administrators and management - escalate critical situation immediately
Investigate counter design - verify counter size is appropriate for system requirements
Plan device replacement - schedule immediate replacement of the device
Decommission device - safely decommission the device according to policy

postconditionality.state: The requested transaction is not created due to counter overflow.
The counter remains at maximum and cannot be incremented.
The device cannot process any new transactions - counter overflow is permanent.
Allowing counter to wrap would compromise audit trail integrity.
The device has reached the end of its useful transaction processing life.
The device must be replaced or decommissioned.

notes.note: Indication: Signature counter would overflow - maximum capacity exceeded
Topics: Signature Operations, Counter Management, Resource Limits, Overflow Protection

scenario.name: Scenario 1: Counter Overflow After Decades of Operation
scenario.description: A device has been in production for 20+ years processing millions of transactions daily. A startTransaction call finally receives ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow. The counter has reached its maximum after processing billions of transactions. The device is decommissioned and replaced.
scenario.errorContext: Device end-of-life due to counter overflow after decades of operation

scenario.name: Scenario 2: Counter Monitoring Predicts Overflow
scenario.description: Capacity planning tools monitor counter growth rates and predict when counters will overflow based on current transaction volume. For a device projected to overflow in 5 years, replacement is scheduled proactively.
scenario.errorContext: Proactive planning detects future counter overflow risk

scenario.name: Scenario 3: Unexpected Counter Overflow Detection
scenario.description: A system experiences unexpected transaction processing failure. Investigation reveals a startTransaction call receives ErrorSignatureCounterOverflow. Analysis shows the counter was undersized for the actual transaction volume. Emergency device replacement is performed and counter sizing is reviewed.
scenario.errorContext: Emergency handling of unexpected counter overflow due to undersized counter

scenario.name: Scenario 4: High-Load System Counter Management
scenario.description: A high-volume transaction system monitors counter increment rates. When counter is predicted to overflow in 2 months at current load, the system schedules gradual migration of transactions to replacement devices to maintain continuous service.
scenario.errorContext: Managed transition planning for high-load systems with predictable counter overflow

implementationContext.note: Counter maximum value should be well-documented (e.g., 2^64-1 for 64-bit counter)
Counter size should be chosen to vastly exceed expected device lifetime and transaction volume
Device should check for counter overflow before attempting increment
Error messages should clearly indicate counter is at maximum value
Device firmware should provide status API to query counter value and maximum
Monitoring should provide early warning when counter approaches maximum (80%+ capacity)
Counter overflow check must prevent counter from wrapping to zero
Device should never silently wrap counter to zero - overflow must always be reported
Documentation should clearly explain counter capacity and expected device lifetime
Capacity planning tools should model counter growth and predict overflow timing
